title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Dextromethorphan is a drug used in many over-the-counter cough and cold medicines for its antitussive effects. It comes in oral strips, lozenges, liquids, or liquid-filled capsules and formulations often combine the drug with guaifenesin, acetaminophen, and pseudoephedrine. Dextromethorphan is also a commonly abused drug because of its euphoric, hallucinogenic, and dissociative properties. This activity reviews the presentation, evaluation, and management of dextromethorphan toxicity and stresses the role of an interprofessional team approach to the care of affected patients.

Dextromethorphan is also a commonly abused drug because of its euphoric, hallucinogenic, and dissociative properties. This activity reviews the presentation, evaluation, and management of dextromethorphan toxicity and stresses the role of an interprofessional team approach to the care of affected patients.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Review the pathophysiology of dextromethorphan toxicity. Describe the history and physical exam findings typically seen in patients with dextromethorphan toxicity Summarize the treatment of dextromethorphan toxicity. Explain modalities to improve care coordination among interprofessional team members to improve outcomes for patients affected by dextromethorphan toxicity. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Introduction
content: Dextromethorphan is a drug used in many over-the-counter cough and cold medicines for its antitussive effects. [1] It comes in oral strips, lozenges, liquids, or liquid-filled capsules and formulations often combine the drug with guaifenesin, acetaminophen, and pseudoephedrine. [1] Dextromethorphan is also a commonly abused drug because of its euphoric, hallucinogenic, and dissociative properties. [2] Some street names for dextromethorphan are “Triple C,” “Dex,” “Orange Crush,” “Red Devils,” and “Poor Man’s PCP.” [2] Depending on the amount ingested, dextromethorphan toxicity can have a wide range of cardiovascular, neurological, metabolic, and musculoskeletal adverse effects. [3] Emergency department providers should become familiar with how to manage patients with dextromethorphan toxicity since hypertension, seizures, tachycardia, psychosis, and rhabdomyolysis are several of the complications that can arise. [3]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Introduction. Dextromethorphan is a drug used in many over-the-counter cough and cold medicines for its antitussive effects. [1] It comes in oral strips, lozenges, liquids, or liquid-filled capsules and formulations often combine the drug with guaifenesin, acetaminophen, and pseudoephedrine. [1] Dextromethorphan is also a commonly abused drug because of its euphoric, hallucinogenic, and dissociative properties. [2] Some street names for dextromethorphan are “Triple C,” “Dex,” “Orange Crush,” “Red Devils,” and “Poor Man’s PCP.” [2] Depending on the amount ingested, dextromethorphan toxicity can have a wide range of cardiovascular, neurological, metabolic, and musculoskeletal adverse effects. [3] Emergency department providers should become familiar with how to manage patients with dextromethorphan toxicity since hypertension, seizures, tachycardia, psychosis, and rhabdomyolysis are several of the complications that can arise. [3]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Etiology
content: The use and misuse of dextromethorphan can cause dextromethorphan toxicity. [3]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Etiology. The use and misuse of dextromethorphan can cause dextromethorphan toxicity. [3]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Epidemiology
content: Dextromethorphan received FA approval in 1958. Recreational misuse began shortly thereafter. Drug companies attempted to blunt its misuse by developing liquid formations that required consumption of a significant amount for CNS effects to be achieved. However, misuse was still common. In the United States, abuse of dextromethorphan leads to approximately 6000 emergency department visits a year. [3] Fifty percent of all emergency department visits due to dextromethorphan toxicity occur in patients between the ages of 12 and 20.  Dextromethorphan is often combined with antihistamines, pseudoephedrine, and acetaminophen in many cough and cold medications, which can cause additional adverse clinical effects in the setting of overdose. [1] Ethanol is a common coingestant. [4] Abusers will sometimes attempt to extract dextromethorphan from the cough and cold medications by performing a 1 or 2 phase acid extraction using household products such as ammonia, lighter fluid, and lemon juice. [5]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Epidemiology. Dextromethorphan received FA approval in 1958. Recreational misuse began shortly thereafter. Drug companies attempted to blunt its misuse by developing liquid formations that required consumption of a significant amount for CNS effects to be achieved. However, misuse was still common. In the United States, abuse of dextromethorphan leads to approximately 6000 emergency department visits a year. [3] Fifty percent of all emergency department visits due to dextromethorphan toxicity occur in patients between the ages of 12 and 20.  Dextromethorphan is often combined with antihistamines, pseudoephedrine, and acetaminophen in many cough and cold medications, which can cause additional adverse clinical effects in the setting of overdose. [1] Ethanol is a common coingestant. [4] Abusers will sometimes attempt to extract dextromethorphan from the cough and cold medications by performing a 1 or 2 phase acid extraction using household products such as ammonia, lighter fluid, and lemon juice. [5]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Pathophysiology
content: Dextrorphan, the active metabolite of dextromethorphan, causes a variety of physiological effects via several different mechanisms. Like ketamine and phencyclidine, dextrorphan blocks NMDA receptors resulting in hallucinations, euphoria, dissociation, agitations, and coma. [3] Dextrorphan binds serotonin receptors, potentially leading to serotonin syndrome (seizures, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, rhabdomyolysis). [6] [7] [8] This activity can occur in the settings of overdose and standard doses when combining dextromethorphan with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs, cocaine, TCAs, or other serotonergic agents. [7] [8] Dextrorphan also blocks the reuptake of peripheral adrenergic neurotransmitters, causing hypertension, tachycardia, mydriasis, and diaphoresis. [3] [2] Dextrorphan does not bind mu or delta opioid receptors but binds sigma opioid receptors leading to antitussive effects. [1]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Pathophysiology. Dextrorphan, the active metabolite of dextromethorphan, causes a variety of physiological effects via several different mechanisms. Like ketamine and phencyclidine, dextrorphan blocks NMDA receptors resulting in hallucinations, euphoria, dissociation, agitations, and coma. [3] Dextrorphan binds serotonin receptors, potentially leading to serotonin syndrome (seizures, muscle rigidity, autonomic instability, rhabdomyolysis). [6] [7] [8] This activity can occur in the settings of overdose and standard doses when combining dextromethorphan with SSRIs, SNRIs, MAOIs, cocaine, TCAs, or other serotonergic agents. [7] [8] Dextrorphan also blocks the reuptake of peripheral adrenergic neurotransmitters, causing hypertension, tachycardia, mydriasis, and diaphoresis. [3] [2] Dextrorphan does not bind mu or delta opioid receptors but binds sigma opioid receptors leading to antitussive effects. [1]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Toxicokinetics
content: Dextromethorphan has a half-life of 3 to 30 hours.  It is metabolized in the liver by the cytochrome p450 system and is mainly excreted by the kidneys. [3] The volume distribution is 5 to 6.7 L/kg. [3] Peak plasma concentration occurs at 2.5 hours. [9] In immediate-release formulations, standard doses range from 5mg to 30mg with the maximum amount of 120mg in a 24 hour period. [9] In extended released formations, 60mg is the standard dose with a maximum amount of 120mg in a 24 hour period.  At doses of 100mg to 300 mg, symptoms ranging from mild stimulation to euphoria and hallucinations can occur.  At doses of 300mg to 600mg, dissociation can occur. At doses of 600mg or higher, complete dissociation and coma can occur. [9]

[3] Peak plasma concentration occurs at 2.5 hours. [9] In immediate-release formulations, standard doses range from 5mg to 30mg with the maximum amount of 120mg in a 24 hour period. [9] In extended released formations, 60mg is the standard dose with a maximum amount of 120mg in a 24 hour period.  At doses of 100mg to 300 mg, symptoms ranging from mild stimulation to euphoria and hallucinations can occur.  At doses of 300mg to 600mg, dissociation can occur. At doses of 600mg or higher, complete dissociation and coma can occur. [9]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- History and Physical
content: Depending on the dose and coingestants, dextromethorphan can cause a broad spectrum of clinical effects ranging from mild agitation to psychosis to seizures and coma. Many times, patients are unable to give a clear history due to altered mental status. Obtaining a history from emergency medical personnel, family, friends, and witnesses can be helpful. Familiarity with street names for dextromethorphan can be helpful as well. General – hyperthermia, diaphoresis, altered mental status (ranging from mild agitation to coma) HEENT – mydriasis, nystagmus Cardiovascular – tachycardia, hypertension Respiratory- respiratory depression Neurological – mild to severe agitation, confusion, hallucination, ataxia, muscular rigidity, seizures, coma
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- History and Physical. Many times, patients are unable to give a clear history due to altered mental status. Obtaining a history from emergency medical personnel, family, friends, and witnesses can be helpful. Familiarity with street names for dextromethorphan can be helpful as well. General – hyperthermia, diaphoresis, altered mental status (ranging from mild agitation to coma) HEENT – mydriasis, nystagmus Cardiovascular – tachycardia, hypertension Respiratory- respiratory depression Neurological – mild to severe agitation, confusion, hallucination, ataxia, muscular rigidity, seizures, coma

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- History and Physical
content: Trauma -  thorough examination for evidence of trauma should take place in the examination as injury secondary to dextromethorphan intoxication can occur due to altered mental status. [3] [4] [8] [10]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- History and Physical. Trauma -  thorough examination for evidence of trauma should take place in the examination as injury secondary to dextromethorphan intoxication can occur due to altered mental status. [3] [4] [8] [10]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: The workup considered should include the following:
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. The workup considered should include the following:

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Dextromethorphan level - not available at many hospitals
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Dextromethorphan level - not available at many hospitals

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Fingerstick blood glucose - helpful in all patients with altered mental status
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Fingerstick blood glucose - helpful in all patients with altered mental status

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Complete blood count – leukocytosis can be seen
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Complete blood count – leukocytosis can be seen

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Basic metabolic panel- identify electrolyte abnormalities, evaluation of kidney function as dextromethorphan predominantly undergoes renal excretion.
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Basic metabolic panel- identify electrolyte abnormalities, evaluation of kidney function as dextromethorphan predominantly undergoes renal excretion.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Liver function tests - acetaminophen can be toxic to the liver and is often combined with dextromethorphan in many medications.
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Liver function tests - acetaminophen can be toxic to the liver and is often combined with dextromethorphan in many medications.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Creatine kinase - evaluation for rhabdomyolysis
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Creatine kinase - evaluation for rhabdomyolysis

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Acetaminophen level - acetaminophen is often combined with dextromethorphan in many medications.
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Acetaminophen level - acetaminophen is often combined with dextromethorphan in many medications.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Salicylate level - helpful in evaluating patients with acid-base disturbances, altered mental status
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Salicylate level - helpful in evaluating patients with acid-base disturbances, altered mental status

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Ethanol level is useful in evaluating patients with altered mental status and is often a coingestant with dextromethorphan toxicity.
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Ethanol level is useful in evaluating patients with altered mental status and is often a coingestant with dextromethorphan toxicity.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: EKG - evaluation tachycardia
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. EKG - evaluation tachycardia

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Imaging studies - should be performed when there is a concern for trauma or aspiration secondary to dextromethorphan toxicity.
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Imaging studies - should be performed when there is a concern for trauma or aspiration secondary to dextromethorphan toxicity.

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation
content: Urine drug screen- can be helpful to identify potential substance coingestion [3] [6] [9]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Evaluation. Urine drug screen- can be helpful to identify potential substance coingestion [3] [6] [9]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management
content: Most patients with dextromethorphan toxicity are successfully managed with supportive care. Airway, breathing, circulation, and hemodynamic monitoring are essential to the care of patients with dextromethorphan toxicity. Intubation with ventilator support may be necessary for airway protection.  A medical toxicologist consult should also take place. [9]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management. Most patients with dextromethorphan toxicity are successfully managed with supportive care. Airway, breathing, circulation, and hemodynamic monitoring are essential to the care of patients with dextromethorphan toxicity. Intubation with ventilator support may be necessary for airway protection.  A medical toxicologist consult should also take place. [9]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management
content: Sedation with medication and physical restraints may be required to control agitation, violent behavior, and psychosis due to dextromethorphan toxicity. Placing the patient in a calm environment such as a quiet room with the light dimmed may be helpful. Benzodiazepines are the preferred medication for chemical sedation in patients with dextromethorphan toxicity. Lorazepam 2 mg to 4 mg intravenous or intramuscular is recommended for chemical sedation. Repeated doses every 10 minutes may be required for adequate sedation. [3]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management. Sedation with medication and physical restraints may be required to control agitation, violent behavior, and psychosis due to dextromethorphan toxicity. Placing the patient in a calm environment such as a quiet room with the light dimmed may be helpful. Benzodiazepines are the preferred medication for chemical sedation in patients with dextromethorphan toxicity. Lorazepam 2 mg to 4 mg intravenous or intramuscular is recommended for chemical sedation. Repeated doses every 10 minutes may be required for adequate sedation. [3]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management
content: Gastrointestinal decontamination with activated charcoal is most efficacious for dextromethorphan overdose when given within one hour of ingestion.  Activated charcoal (1 g/kg, max 50g) by mouth or nasogastric tube is recommended if there are no contraindications to activated charcoal. Gastric lavage or induced emesis is not recommended. [9] Naloxone can treat respiratory depression and central nervous system depression due to dextromethorphan toxicity. Naloxone 0.1mg/kg with a maximum dose of 2mg IV is the recommendation. [11] Hyperthermia induced by dextromethorphan toxicity should be treated with active cooling measures such as evaporative cooling, cold IV fluids, and cold inspired oxygen. [4] [9]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management. Gastrointestinal decontamination with activated charcoal is most efficacious for dextromethorphan overdose when given within one hour of ingestion.  Activated charcoal (1 g/kg, max 50g) by mouth or nasogastric tube is recommended if there are no contraindications to activated charcoal. Gastric lavage or induced emesis is not recommended. [9] Naloxone can treat respiratory depression and central nervous system depression due to dextromethorphan toxicity. Naloxone 0.1mg/kg with a maximum dose of 2mg IV is the recommendation. [11] Hyperthermia induced by dextromethorphan toxicity should be treated with active cooling measures such as evaporative cooling, cold IV fluids, and cold inspired oxygen. [4] [9]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management
content: It is important to consider that dextromethorphan is routinely combined with acetaminophen, decongestants, and antihistamines in many cough and cold medications, evaluating and treating acetaminophen toxicity decongestant toxicity and anticholinergic toxicity should be considered. [3] [12]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management. It is important to consider that dextromethorphan is routinely combined with acetaminophen, decongestants, and antihistamines in many cough and cold medications, evaluating and treating acetaminophen toxicity decongestant toxicity and anticholinergic toxicity should be considered. [3] [12]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management
content: Patients with dextromethorphan toxicity can be discharged home if they are asymptomatic for six hours after ingestion if they are not suicidal and have a negative acetaminophen level. Symptomatic patients and patients with complications such as hyperthermia, serotonin syndrome, hypertensive crisis, or rhabdomyolysis should be admitted to the ICU. Patients who are suicidal should have a psychiatric consultation. [3] [4]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Treatment / Management. Patients with dextromethorphan toxicity can be discharged home if they are asymptomatic for six hours after ingestion if they are not suicidal and have a negative acetaminophen level. Symptomatic patients and patients with complications such as hyperthermia, serotonin syndrome, hypertensive crisis, or rhabdomyolysis should be admitted to the ICU. Patients who are suicidal should have a psychiatric consultation. [3] [4]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Differential Diagnosis
content: Alcohol intoxication Amphetamine intoxication Anticholinergic poisoning Bipolar disorder Brain neoplasms Cocaine toxicity Diphenhydramine toxicity Delirium tremors Encephalitis Hyperthyroidism Hypoglycemia Hyponatremia Hypoxia Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) toxicity Malignant hyperthermia MDMA toxicity Neuroleptic malignant syndrome Serotonin syndrome Salicylate poisoning Toxic alcohol poisoning Trauma (self-induced or accidental) Meningitis/encephalitis Schizophrenia Sepsis SSRI toxicity [3] [4] [13]

Alcohol intoxication Amphetamine intoxication Anticholinergic poisoning Bipolar disorder Brain neoplasms Cocaine toxicity Diphenhydramine toxicity Delirium tremors Encephalitis Hyperthyroidism Hypoglycemia Hyponatremia Hypoxia Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) toxicity Malignant hyperthermia MDMA toxicity Neuroleptic malignant syndrome Serotonin syndrome Salicylate poisoning Toxic alcohol poisoning Trauma (self-induced or accidental) Meningitis/encephalitis Schizophrenia Sepsis SSRI toxicity [3] [4] [13]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Prognosis
content: Management of most patients with dextromethorphan toxicity is with supportive care. Airway, breathing, circulation, and hemodynamic monitoring are essential to the care of patients with dextromethorphan toxicity. Intubation with ventilator support may be necessary for airway protection. [4]

Airway, breathing, circulation, and hemodynamic monitoring are essential to the care of patients with dextromethorphan toxicity. Intubation with ventilator support may be necessary for airway protection. [4]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Complications
content: Seizures Hypertensive emergency Coma Serotonin syndrome Rhabdomyolysis Psychosis Respiration depression/apnea [3] [4] [12]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Complications. Seizures Hypertensive emergency Coma Serotonin syndrome Rhabdomyolysis Psychosis Respiration depression/apnea [3] [4] [12]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: All patients should receive education about the dangers of dextromethorphan. Parents should be told to store dextromethorphan out of the reach of children. [3]
contents: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Deterrence and Patient Education. All patients should receive education about the dangers of dextromethorphan. Parents should be told to store dextromethorphan out of the reach of children. [3]

title: Dextromethorphan Toxicity -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Dextromethorphan toxicity is best managed by an interprofessional healthcare team comprised of clinicians, mid-level practitioners, nurses, pharmacists, and mental health professionals. This drug can affect the central nervous system, cardiovascular system, and musculoskeletal system. All patients should receive counsel about the dangers of dextromethorphan. Parents should be instructed to store dextromethorphan out of the reach of children. For patients who intentionally overdose, a behavioral health consult is a strong recommendation. [3] [4] [9] With an interprofessional team approach, patients can get the care they need to recover from dextromethorphan toxicity, prevent accidental toxicity, and obtain assistance in cases of deliberate toxicity, leading to patient outcomes. [Level 5]

[3] [4] [9] With an interprofessional team approach, patients can get the care they need to recover from dextromethorphan toxicity, prevent accidental toxicity, and obtain assistance in cases of deliberate toxicity, leading to patient outcomes. [Level 5]
